text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with savory bacon and crab bread
pudding benedict that's right this was
supposed to be crab cake Benedict but I
figured we'd already done crab cakes so
let's do something inspired by that idea
but completely different and this was
one of the most incredibly delicious
things I've eaten in a long time so to
start we're going to need some dried
bread cubes just like the ones used for
Thanksgiving stuffing so I just cubed up
some stale sourdough I had put it in the
oven till it was dry and crisp you could
also use a plain prepared crouton but
obviously very simple to make your own
so we have our bread cubes in a bowl and
we're on to the good stuff like bacon
and we don't need much that's just one
slice that I cut up I put a few drips of
vegetable oil in a saute pan on a medium
heat and we're simply going to cook that
until almost crisp and when it looks
like that we're gonna add some onions
but before we do I need you to swab out
all that excess grease just use some
tongs in a paper towel all right we're
going to put a little cream in this and
I don't want to use up all my calories
with bacon fat so get rid of all that at
that point we're going to dump in our
minced onions and again we're over
medium heat so tossing the onions we're
going to give them about a two minute
saute where they're just going to start
to turn translucent at that point I'm
going to dump in my diced red pepper
just a little bit by the way you know my
chefs usually put finely diced red
pepper in things with crab because
visually it makes it look like there's
more crab in something chefs are like
just under James Bond villains as far as
being devious so be careful all right so
we're gonna cook the peppers just for
about a minute and then we're going to
add our liquid which is chicken broth
and a little splash of cream and by the
way if you don't want to use chicken
broth you can use water but don't use
fish stock crabs not supposed to taste
like fish all right so we're going to
give that a stir and as soon as it
starts to boil like that turn it off and
we're going to dump that over our dried
bread cubes now very important here as
soon as you dump that liquid in I want
you to give it a stir and keep stirring
until all the liquid is absorbed if you
just dump that in and then go grab the
rest of the ingredients some of the
bread cubes will be totally saturated
some will still be dry so as soon as you
dump it in I want you to toss toss toss
until you don't see any liquid left and
then we can move on to the rest of the
ingredients at that point we're going to
toss in some freshly
rated lemon zest and also the juice from
half a lemon which by the way works out
perfectly because I'm going to use the
other half of the lemon for my
hollandaise all right so I'm going to
squeeze that in I'm also going to add
some freshly chopped tarragon and one
whole large egg I'm going to switch to a
spatula I'm going to give that egg a
little beating and then we're going to
toss that all together so once that's
thoroughly combined
we're going to add the final and most
important ingredient fresh sweet awesome
crab I'm using Dungeness because that's
what we eat here in San Francisco but
wherever you're from find the best
sweetest freshest crab you can and put
that in here and you'll notice I'm
putting in little pinch at a time that
way you can feel for little shells or
that membrane that cartilage that
sometimes you get in crab as you're
dumping this in just put a pinch at a
time with your fingers you'll be able to
find that stuff ok so once our crab is
in we're going to season this up a
little bit I'm going to use a little bit
of freshly ground black pepper some
cayenne I know you're shocked and a nice
pinch of salt and when that's mixed in
you're basically done if you feel the
mixture is moist enough okay so
depending on how dry your croutons or
bread cubes are you may need to add a
little tiny splash of stock and or cream
like I just did here just to give it a
little extra moisture so that's really
you going by feel
it should not be sopping wet it should
not be dry it should just be moist
throughout so I'm going to leave that up
to you because you are after all the
boss of your bread pudding all right
once that's mixed in we are ready for
the oven I have some buttered ramekins
I'm just making two portions here but
this recipe is very easy to scale up so
I'm going to divide my mixture evenly
between the two ramekins and make sure
you even it out nicely alright we're
going to put those on a baking sheet and
pop those in a preheated 400 degree oven
for about 20 minutes everything in here
is basically cooked so all you want is
it to be heated completely through and
for the top to be kind of golden brown
and crusty and that's what we have right
there and I'm telling you just that
right there would be a delicious tasty
treat but we didn't stop there
we put this on a plate topped it with a
couple poached eggs one would have been
fine
but I'm more of a two egg person so two
perfectly poached eggs and then a little
bit of hollandaise a nice light version
very lemony not that thick gloppy stuff
that looks like lemon pudding you see on
some brunch dish
and of course a little dusting of
cayenne and that was amazing there's
just no way that's not going to taste
incredible but just to be sure
I need to check so here we go so you got
that very subtle smokiness from the
bacon that sweet Dungeness crab the
aromatic vegetables the lemon and the
tarragon balancing everything perfectly
just everything about this worked not
very hard to make it all and like I said
at the beginning this was one of the
most spectacular ly delicious things
I've had in a really really long time
would be awesome for any special brunch
especially that Mother's Day brunch in
end so head over to food wishes calm to
get all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
